latestVersion.disclaimer:
IFPRI adheres to the principle of unrestricted public access to its own final research outputs and will make such outputs freely available. The Institute encourages the use of the Pakistan Cotton Survey 2015, Round 2.1 dataset; for detailed information on its use, please refer to IFPRI’s Intellectual Property Policy. The data files in this dataset are unit record or ‘raw’ data files. Information that would allow survey respondents to be identified has been deleted from the files, but all other information remains. IFPRI’s decision not to alter the contents of the data files means that the user of these files will need to take care in handling missing observations, outliers, and violations of logical consistency.

The data are provided ‘as is’ and in no event shall IFPRI be liable for any damages resulting from use of the data. While great effort was taken to obtain high-quality data, the accuracy or reliability of the data is not guaranteed or warranted in anyway.

dsDescriptionValue.value:
The dataset "Pakistan Cotton Survey 2015, Round 2.1" was collected to inform the research study that examines the efficiency of markets for cotton seed in Pakistan with particular emphasis on the market for genetically modified cotton seed embodying insect-resistance traits from the soil bacterium Bacillus thurigiensis (Bt) that have been conferred through genetic modification.

The survey was designed by the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) and implemented by Innovative Development Studies (IDS). It was a second round of the panel survey and covered similar modules as Round 1.1 and Round 1.3 (land utilization, labor, machinery, and draught power usage and expenditure, use of pesticide and insecticide, expenditure on inputs, cotton harvest and sales, household income, shocks, agricultural credit, and access to extension) for kharif 2014. It also included a discrete choice experiment to understand cotton farmers’ attitudes and perceptions regarding cotton leaf curl virus (CLCV) resistant varieties and related traits.

publicationCitation.value: Spielman, David J.; Nazli, Hina; Ma, Xingliang; Zambrano, Patricia; and Zaidi, Fatima. 2015. Technological Opportunity, Regulatory Uncertainty, and Bt cotton in Pakistan. AgBioForum 18 (1): 98–112.

Ma, Xingliang; Smale, Melinda; Spielman, David J.; Zambrano, Patricia; Nazli, Hina and Zaidi, Fatima. 2016. Varietal integrity, damage abatement, and productivity: Evidence from the cultivation of Bt cotton in Pakistan. IFPRI Discussion Paper 1520. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

Ma, Xingliang; Smale, Melinda; Spielman, David J.; Zambrano, Patricia; Nazli, Hina; and Zaidi, Fatima. A question of integrity: Variants of Bt Cotton, pesticides and productivity in Pakistan. Journal of Agricultural Economics. Article in press. First published online on July 4, 2016.

Zaidi, Fatima; Zambrano Patricia; Khan, Asif Ali; Ali, Shaukat; Cheema, H. Masooma Naseer; Ma Xingliang; Nazli, Hina; Khan, Sohail Ahmad; Iqbal, Arshad; Zia, Muhammad Amir; Ali, Ghulam Muhammad; and Spielman, David J. What are farmers really planting? Measuring the presence and effectiveness of Bt cotton in Pakistan. Paper presented at the 20th annual conference of the International Consortium on Applied Bioeconomy Research (ICABR), Ravello, Italy, June 26-29.

grantNumberAgency.value: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

value: Cotton farmers in cotton-growing agro-climatic zones in both Punjab and Sindh Provinces of Pakistan. More specifically, the selection criteria for individual participation in this study is whether he or she is a member of a household that has cultivated cotton in the past one year in a randomly selected revenue village in the main cotton-growing agro-ecological zones of Punjab or Sindh provinces of Pakistan. To the extent possible, individual participation will be limited to the household head and spouse of household head which, in the context of Pakistani households, are always assumed to be adults over the age of 18 years.

fields.value: Data Collector Innovative Development Strategies (Pvt) Ltd.

Data were collected in face-to-face interviews with 728 farmers who were selected in a statistically representative sample of all cotton-growing agro-climatic zones in both Punjab and Sindh Provinces, accounting for more than 99 percent of the cotton cultivated in Pakistan. Households were selected in a two-stage sampling procedure stratified by cotton-growing agro-climatic zones. In the first stage, 52 villages are chosen with probabilities that were proportional to farming population sizes. In the second stage, 14 cotton households are chosen from each village with equal probability of selection.
